Disciples, from immeasurable eons ago up to the present day, in between we have created various karmas.
Karmas can adorn the worldly paths, in every place and situation, therefore we contemplate seeking to leave the world and attain liberation.
Thus, the fruits and retributions of the six paths are of various kinds, with different forms and species, we should know that they are all created by the power of karma.
Therefore, among the ten powers of the Buddha, the power of karma is very profound.
Ordinary people often give rise to doubts in this regard:
Why is it so?
'One can see in the world that those who do good encounter difficulties,
while those who do evil have things go smoothly, and they say:
'There is no distinction between good and evil in the world.
' Those who think like this all fail to deeply understand the principle of karma.
Why is this so?
The sutras say:
'There are three kinds of karma.
What are the three?
First, karma with immediate retribution; second, karma with retribution in the next life; third, karma with retribution in a later life.

Karma with immediate retribution means creating good or evil in the present life and receiving retribution in this body;ğŸ”½karma with retribution in the next life means creating good or evil in this life and receiving retribution in the next life;
karma with retribution in a later life means creating good or evil in the past, in countless lifetimes, and either receiving retribution in this life or in future lifetimes.
Those who previously engaged in evil but now see goodness, this is due to the ripening of wholesome karma from past lives, which results in the present pleasant fruits;
it has nothing to do with creating evil karma in the present and receiving good rewards.

Those who engage in wholesome deeds but now see suffering, this is due to the ripening of unwholesome karma from past lives, which results in the present weak wholesome roots being unable to dispel it, and thus they receive this painful retribution;
it has nothing to do with creating wholesome karma in the present and inviting evil retribution.
How do we know this to be so?
We currently see in the world that those who do good are praised by others and respected by people, so we know that in the future they will definitely receive pleasant fruits.
Since there is such unwholesome karma from the past, the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas teach us to be close to good friends and together repent.
Good and virtuous friends are completely beneficial in attaining the Way in this life.
Therefore, disciples, today with utmost sincerity, we take refuge in all Buddhas.

Disciples, having now repented all karmas in general, we should now repent each one in detail. Whether general or specific, coarse or fine, light or heavy, spoken or unspoken, we vow to eliminate them all.
As for specific repentance, we first repent the three karmas of the body, then the four karmas of speech, and the other hindrances, we repent each one in turn.
As for the three karmas of the body, the first is killing, as explained in the sutras. Treat others as you would yourself, do not kill, do not use a whip.

Although there is a difference between birds and beasts, the matter of cherishing life and fearing death is the same. If we trace these sentient beings back to beginningless time, they may have been our parents, siblings, or relatives of the six kinds, and due to karmic causes and conditions, they have been transmigrating through the six realms, being born and dying, changing forms and undergoing transformations, and we no longer recognize each other. Yet now we harm and eat their flesh, which is the utmost cruelty. Therefore, the Buddha said:
Even if you obtain leftover food, you should think of it as eating your child's flesh in a famine, let alone eating fish and meat.
He also said:
Those who kill sentient beings for profit and those who pay for meat, both commit evil karma and fall into the wailing hell.
Therefore, we know that the sin of killing and eating is deeper than the ocean and heavier than a mountain.
However, disciples, from beginningless time, we have not encountered good friends, and all this is due to this karma.
Therefore, the sutra says:
'The sin of killing can cause sentient beings to fall into the hells and hungry ghost realms to suffer.

If in the animal realm, they will receive the bodies of tigers, leopards, jackals, wolves, hawks, and falcons, or the bodies of poisonous snakes, vipers, and scorpions, always harboring evil thoughts, or the bodies of deer, bears, and other animals, always in fear.
If reborn among humans, they will receive two kinds of karmic retribution: first, much illness; second, short life.'
Killing and eating living beings thus has such immeasurable various evil karmic retributions.

Sometimes setting fires with the wind, flying kites and chasing dogs, harming all beings - such sins are immeasurable and boundless, I repent of them all with utmost sincerity today.
Or using fences, traps, pits, spears, halberds, bows and crossbows to shoot flying birds and running beasts;

Or using nets, traps, hooks and measures to catch aquatic creatures such as fish, turtles, alligators, shrimp, clams, snails and oysters that live in wet places, causing those that live in water, on land and in the air to have no place to hide;
Or raising chickens, pigs, cows, sheep, dogs, pigs, geese and ducks to supply one's own kitchen;

Or selling them to be slaughtered, causing their mournful cries to end, their feathers to fall off, their scales and shells to be damaged, their bodies and heads to be separated, their bones and flesh to be crushed, their skin to be flayed, their meat to be cut up, and to be roasted, boiled and grilled, inflicting cruel and harmful punishments unjustly, just for a moment's pleasure, with the tongue getting very few flavors, no more than three inches of the tongue root;ğŸ”½Yet the retribution for these sins brings misfortune and binds one for eternal kalpas.
Such sins are immeasurable and boundless, but today I sincerely repent of them all.

Furthermore, since beginningless time, we have either aborted fetuses or destroyed eggs, used poisonous drugs or sorcery, harmed and killed sentient beings, tilled the soil, planted fields and gardens, raised silkworms and boiled cocoons, causing great harm and killing;
Or we have beaten mosquitoes and flies, slapped and bitten lice and fleas;
Or we have burned rubbish, opened ditches and canals, and wantonly harmed all;
Or we have eaten fruits;
Or we have used grains, water, or vegetables to kill sentient beings;
Or we have burned firewood or exposed lamps and candles, burning various insects;
Or we have eaten sauces and vinegar without looking to see if they are moving;
Or we have poured boiling water, drowning insects and ants.
In this way, in the four deportments of walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, we have always harmed and killed the subtle sentient beings in the air and on the ground.
The disciples, with our unenlightened and ignorant minds, have not been aware of this. Today, we sincerely repent of all of it.

Moreover, disciples, from beginningless time until today, we have used whips, sticks, fetters, chains, beaten, struck, kicked with our hands and feet, bound, caged, and cut off water and grain, in these various evil ways, we have caused suffering to sentient beings.
Today, with utmost sincerity, we repent of all of this.

We wish that by repenting of the offenses of killing and harming, the disciples will give rise to merit and virtue. Life after life, may they attain the vajra body with an infinite lifespan. Forever free from resentment and hatred, without thoughts of killing and harming. Towards all sentient beings, may they attain the state of mind of regarding all as one's only child. If they see those in danger and distress, without regard for their own lives, they will skillfully rescue and liberate them. Afterwards, they will expound the subtle and correct Dharma, causing all sentient beings who see their form or shadow to be granted peace and joy. Hearing their name or voice, all fear will be eliminated. Having repented and made vows, they take refuge and pay homage to the Three Jewels.

Homage to the Buddhas of the past, present, and future, in the ten directions and the three periods of time, throughout the entire realm of space, I take refuge and repent:
With utmost sincerity, I repent!
Disciples, since beginningless time until today, we have either stolen others' wealth and treasures, wielding weapons to forcefully take them;
Or relying on our own power, we have oppressed and taken them;

Or relying on official authority or power, we have set up high gallows and large shackles to unjustly oppress the righteous, swallowing bribes, torturing the honest to make them seem guilty, for these causes and conditions, we have entangled ourselves in the legal net;

Or unjustly punishing others, taking their wealth, encroaching on public goods for private gain, encroaching on private goods for public gain, harming others for one's own benefit, harming oneself for others' benefit, cutting others to benefit oneself, giving with the mouth while begrudging in the heart;
Or stealing and evading taxes, smuggling across customs, concealing public levies and taxes, hiding from public service.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless, and I now repent of them all with utmost sincerity.

Whether it is property belonging to the Buddha, Dharma, or Sangha, or property belonging to the monastic community, if I have stolen, misused, or failed to return it out of arrogance, borrowed it myself, lent it to others, or exchanged it with loss or forgetfulness;

Or if I have mixed and used the property of the Three Jewels indiscriminately, or used the goods, grains, firewood, salt, soy sauce, vinegar, vegetables, fruits, money, silk, bamboo, wood, brocade, banners, incense, flowers, and oil lamps of the community as I pleased, either using them myself or giving them to others;
Or plucking the Buddha's flowers and fruits, using the Sangha's possessions, and privately benefiting oneself through the wealth of the Three Jewels.
Such offenses are innumerable and boundless, and I now repent of them all with utmost sincerity.
Furthermore, from beginningless time until today, I may have deceived friends, teachers, classmates, parents, siblings, and relatives with whom I have lived and stayed, in a hundred and one ways.

Or in the neighborhood, I may have moved fences and expanded walls, encroaching on others' houses, changing marks and signs, plundering fields and gardens, taking advantage of public or private matters to seize others' shops and fields.
Such offenses are innumerable and boundless, and I now repent of them all with utmost sincerity.
Furthermore, from beginningless time, I may have attacked cities and villages, burned villages and destroyed barriers, stolen and sold good people, and enticed others' slaves and servants;

Or perhaps unjustly oppressing innocent people, causing their bodies to be emaciated, covered in blood, bound in chains, their family business ruined and scattered, their relatives separated, sent to different regions, separated by life and death, such offenses are immeasurable and boundless, and today we repent of them all with utmost sincerity.

Furthermore, from beginningless time until today, we may have engaged in commerce, trading goods, running inns, or selling in the market, using light weights or small measures, cutting short lengths, stealing even a few grams, deceiving others with ounces or pints, exchanging inferior goods for superior ones, or exchanging short for long, with hundreds of deceptive tricks, hoping for even the slightest profit.
Offenses such as these are immeasurable and boundless, and today we repent of them all with utmost sincerity.

Furthermore, from beginningless time until today, we may have engaged in activities such as tunneling through walls, robbing and plundering, evading debts and interest, reneging on promises, deceiving others to their face while thinking ill of them in our hearts;
Or by non-dharma, violating and taking away the objects of the four types of birth, such as ghosts, spirits, birds, and beasts;
Or by falsely relying on divination and physiognomy to take people's wealth and treasures, up to seeking profit with profit, seeking evil, seeking much, without satiation or contentment.
Such sins are immeasurable and boundless. Today, with utmost sincerity, we repent of them all.

May the disciples, by inheriting the merits born from repenting of the offenses of stealing and so forth, be born in every life with wish-fulfilling jewels, always raining down the seven treasures, the finest garments, the hundred flavors of nectar, and various medicines. Whatever is needed will arrive upon thought. All beings will have no thought of stealing. All will be able to have few desires and be content, not indulging or being attached, always enjoying giving, practicing swift rescue, giving away head, eyes, marrow, and brain as if discarding spittle. Dedicate this to fully perfecting the perfection of giving.
Having repented and made vows, take refuge and pay homage to the Three Jewels.

Or the tongue craves delicious flavors, fresh, sweet, and fatty, the blood and flesh of sentient beings, nourishing the four elements and further increasing the basis of suffering, giving rise to improper thoughts;

Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. Today, with utmost sincerity, I confess to the Buddhas in the ten directions, the honored Dharma, and the noble Sangha.

May disciples, by inheriting the merits born from repenting of the offenses of sexual desire and so forth, be naturally transformed and reborn in every life, not by means of the womb, pure and spotless, with excellent features and radiance, the six faculties clear and bright, intelligent and discerning, thoroughly understanding that affection is like shackles and chains, regarding the six sense objects as illusory and insubstantial, decisively turning away from the objects of the five desires, not giving rise to deviant thoughts even in dreams, and never being moved by internal and external conditions.
Vowing to use the merit of repenting of the eye faculty, may this eye thoroughly see the pure Dharma bodies of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas in the ten directions, without dualistic appearances.

Vowing to use the merit of repenting of the ear faculty, may this ear always hear the true Dharma spoken by the Buddhas and sages in the ten directions, and respectfully practice according to the teachings.

I vow to repent with the merits of the nose faculty, wishing that this nose always smells the fragrant accumulation, enters the fragrance of the Dharma position, and abandons the impure and foul stench of birth and death.

I vow to repent with the merits of the tongue faculty, wishing that this tongue always eats the food of Dharma joy and meditation joy, and does not crave the taste of sentient beings' blood and flesh.

I vow to repent with the merits of the body faculty, wishing that this body wears the Tathagata's robe, dons the armor of forbearance, lies on the bed of fearlessness, and sits on the seat of the four dhyanas.

I vow to repent with the merits of the mind faculty, wishing that this mind accomplishes the ten contemplations, penetrates the five sciences, deeply contemplates the principle of emptiness and equality of the two truths, arises from expedient wisdom to perform the ten wondrous practices, enters the flowing water of the Dharma, and increases in brightness moment by moment, manifesting the Tathagata's great acceptance of non-arising.

Namo to the Buddhas of the past, present, and future, the ten directions and three times, throughout the realm of space, I take refuge and repent:
With utmost sincerity, I repent!
Having already repented all karmic hindrances, I will next repent all hindrances between the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha.
The Buddha said in the sutra:

'The human body is difficult to obtain, the Buddha's teachings are difficult to hear, the Sangha is difficult to encounter, faith is difficult to give rise to, the six sense faculties are difficult to be complete, and good friends are difficult to find.
' But now we have together planted good roots from past lives, obtained this human body with the six sense faculties complete, and again encountered good friends, and can hear the true Dharma.

In the meantime, we have each been unable to wholeheartedly apply ourselves with diligence. Fearing that in the future we will long be submerged in myriad sufferings, without a chance of escape, therefore today we have come to feel shame and remorse, and repent of all our transgressions.
Moreover, from beginningless time up to the present, we have always allowed ignorance to cover our minds and afflictions to obstruct our thoughts;
When seeing the Buddha's images, we have been unable to wholeheartedly be respectful;
We have looked down upon the Sangha, harmed good friends, destroyed stupas and temples, burned images, and drawn blood from the Buddha's body;

Or placing the honored images in a lowly place in one's own flower hall, allowing them to be smoked by incense, exposed to the sun and rain, blown by the wind, covered by dust and dirt, pecked at by sparrows and mice, living together with them without ever paying respect;
Or leaving the image body naked without any adornment;
Or blocking lamps and candles, or closing temple halls, obstructing the Buddha's light.
Such offenses, we now repent of them all.

Furthermore, from beginningless time up to the present, either in the Dharma or in the interval, with impure hands we have held scriptures, or locked them away in boxes eaten by insects and decayed, or the covers have fallen off, the chapters have been lost, the stitching has come undone, the paper and ink have been torn, we have neither repaired them ourselves nor been willing to circulate them.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless, therefore, disciples, we now take refuge in the Buddhas with utmost sincerity.

Repenting with utmost sincerity!
Disciples, from immeasurable eons ago up to the present day, in between, we have committed offenses according to our minds and made mistakes according to our intentions;
This matter is contrary, and we have offended in many ways;
We have taken the three obstructed paths and entered the forest of the eight wrong paths;
We have ascended the platform of afflictions and climbed to the hall of ignorance;ğŸ”½This has caused the meditation pond to dry up, unable to draw the lotus of wisdom;
The tree of precepts has been destroyed, unable to produce the flowers and leaves of samadhi;
In our prime, we have been indulgent and created offenses beyond measure;
Our minds are covered by ignorance, and we have committed many sins;
The ten evil deeds and five heinous crimes are as numerous as the sands of the Ganges;
The three karmas and six sense faculties have offenses that are difficult to describe.
Due to these karmic hindrances, we have burdened our future bodies, and the seeds of retribution have come to the present life, causing us to fall into hell.
Here, the ox-headed guards roar and drag us to the sword mountain, and the prison guards frown and drive us up the tree of swords;
In a single day and night, we die and are reborn ten thousand times;
The flesh is exhausted in the boiling cauldron, the bones are shattered beside the copper pillar;
The iron-beaked bird pecks out the eyes;
The copper-toothed sharp fangs tear at the body and head;
The cold ice, painful charcoal, boil, roast, burn;
The pestle pounds, the mill grinds, the plow plows, the saw cuts - such suffering is immeasurable and boundless, cannot be fully described, cannot be fully spoken of.
Disciples, now in the presence of the Buddhas, Dharma, and Sangha of the ten directions, we confess all our karmic hindrances in general.
With a sincere mind, we repent of the offenses we have committed, and wish that as we repent, they will all be eliminated;
As for those we have not yet committed, from now on we will change our past ways and cultivate in the future, and dare not commit them again.
Having repented and made vows, we take refuge and pay homage to the Three Jewels.
